audience: High school students preparing for the SAT (Reading & Writing)

teacher_notes.pacing: 60–75 minutes; 3 sections with timed drills and review.
teacher_notes.materials: Timer, mixed item sets, and reflection sheets for strategy notes.
teacher_notes.assessment: 4-item unit check and exit reflection on pacing decisions.

learning_objectives: Apply strategies across mixed Reading & Writing items.
Manage time with deliberate skipping and flagging.
Recognize and avoid common traps and pitfalls.

lecture_script.script: On mixed sets, label the question type quickly, predict, then select while eliminating by relevance and precision.
We’ll complete a 3-item mini set under time, then debrief choices in one sentence each.
State the evidence phrase that made your answer correct.

worked_example.passage: The beekeeper recorded hive weights weekly, noting that supplemental flowers near the fence correlated with steadier gains.
worked_example.question: Which choice best states the main idea?

options.B: Nearby flowers were associated with steadier weight gains.

worked_example.explanation: The sentence links supplemental flowers with steadier gains-central relationship.

practice_set.passage: The editor cut redundant phrases so the article would read quickly and clearly.
practice_set.question: The edit primarily aims to improve

practice_set.passage: Figure: A line rises from 10 to 18 between trials 1 and 4.
practice_set.question: Which statement is supported by the figure?

structure.title: Time Management Drills
objectives: Avoid spending more than 30 seconds before moving on.

lecture_script.script: Protect later points by setting 20–30 second decision windows. Make a best choice, flag, and continue.
Run a two-minute drill: answer three items, flag one if needed, and return.
Share one item you flagged and why-you protected time for later points.

worked_example.passage: During a drill, Sam quickly eliminated two options as off-topic, chose the better of the remaining two, and flagged the item.
worked_example.question: Sam’s approach primarily demonstrates
worked_example.explanation: Elimination plus flagging reflects strategic pacing decisions.

practice_set.passage: Facing a dense sentence, Alia selected an answer, flagged the item, and finished the last three questions on time.
practice_set.question: What strategy is illustrated?

structure.title: Common Pitfalls & Review
objectives: Avoid choices that are true but not relevant.
Watch for extreme or absolute wording when the passage is moderate.
Check that grammar edits preserve meaning.

lecture_script.script: Most traps are tempting because they echo the text without answering the question or use extreme language not supported by the passage.
We’ll dissect a distractor that is factually correct but irrelevant and a choice with ‘always’ that overreaches the evidence.
Write one trap pattern you will watch for on test day.

worked_example.passage: Researchers observed that moderate exercise was associated with improved mood in most participants during weekdays.
worked_example.question: Which choice is an overgeneralization?

options.A: Moderate exercise was linked to better mood on weekdays.
options.B: Exercise always guarantees happiness for everyone.

worked_example.explanation: ‘Always’ and ‘everyone’ go beyond the study’s limited claim.

practice_set.passage: The author praises a program for reducing food waste but notes it requires consistent volunteer hours.
practice_set.question: Which choice is not supported?

options.C: The author completely opposes the program.
options.D: There is a noted requirement for effort.

homework: Complete a 12-item mixed set under time and annotate trap patterns.
Create a personal pacing plan with checkpoints every 5 minutes.
Write three ‘if stuck, then’ rules you will apply on test day.
